articles.headline: Why Did Someone Pay $560,000 for a Picture of My Column?
articles.snippet: Bidders say they had many different motivations, including fun, self-promotion and a signal of support for the NFT market.
articles.abstract: Bidders say they had many different motivations, including fun, self-promotion and a signal of support for the NFT market.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’ve had some strange experiences in my career as a journalist. But nothing even remotely prepared me for the experience of watching total strangers competing to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars for a picture of my words.

articles.headline: Georgia G.O.P. Fires Opening Shot in Fight to Limit Voting
articles.snippet: Civil rights groups quickly challenged a new law placing restrictions on voting, while President Biden denounced it as “Jim Crow.” Republicans in other states are determined to follow suit with their own measures.
articles.abstract: Civil rights groups quickly challenged a new law placing restrictions on voting, while President Biden denounced it as “Jim Crow.” Republicans in other states are determined to follow suit with their own measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fight over voting rights is emerging as one of the defining conflicts of the Biden era, and Georgia fired the opening shot with a set of new restrictions underscoring the political, legal and financial clashes that will influence whether Republicans retake Congress and the White House.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Children Trapped by Colombia’s War, Five Years After Peace Deal
articles.snippet: Despite a 2016 peace deal with the FARC, Colombia’s long internal conflict continues. Seldom has that been as evident as this month, when the government bombed a rebel camp full of young people.
articles.abstract: Despite a 2016 peace deal with the FARC, Colombia’s long internal conflict continues. Seldom has that been as evident as this month, when the government bombed a rebel camp full of young people.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUERTO CACHICAMO, Colombia — At 13, she left home to join the guerrillas. Now, at 15, Yeimi Sofía Vega lay in a coffin, killed during a military operation ordered by her government.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Sofía Villamil and Federico Rios

articles.headline: What the Media Has Learned Since Columbine
articles.snippet: After that school shooting, the media faced criticism for focusing on the assailants rather than on the victims. A lot has changed since 1999 — except the need to cover the tragedies.
articles.abstract: After that school shooting, the media faced criticism for focusing on the assailants rather than on the victims. A lot has changed since 1999 — except the need to cover the tragedies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, the CNN anchor Brianna Keilar found herself, for the second time in under a week, guiding viewers through the grim ritual of trying, and failing, to make sense of another mass shooting.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin

articles.headline: In Washington, Policy Revolves Around Joe Manchin. He Likes It That Way.
articles.snippet: Mr. Manchin’s belief in the need to keep the filibuster has set the stage for a collision between Democrats eager to use its majorities to pass sweeping legislation and a political throwback determined to restore bipartisanship.
articles.abstract: Mr. Manchin’s belief in the need to keep the filibuster has set the stage for a collision between Democrats eager to use its majorities to pass sweeping legislation and a political throwback determined to restore bipartisanship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Democrats eliminate the filibuster, there is one senator who would have an outsized impact in the 50-50 chamber on issues that could reshape the nation’s future: infrastructure, immigration, gun laws and voting rights. That senator is Joe Manchin III of West Virginia.

articles.headline: A Collapse Foretold: How Brazil’s Covid-19 Outbreak Overwhelmed Hospitals
articles.snippet: The virus has killed more than 300,000 people in Brazil, its spread aided by a highly contagious variant, political infighting and distrust of science.
articles.abstract: The virus has killed more than 300,000 people in Brazil, its spread aided by a highly contagious variant, political infighting and distrust of science.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil — The patients began arriving at hospitals in Porto Alegre far sicker and younger than before. Funeral homes were experiencing a steady uptick in business, while exhausted doctors and nurses pleaded in February for a lockdown to save lives.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño, Letícia Casado and Mauricio Lima

articles.headline: ‘A Very Big Problem.’ Giant Ship in the Suez Remains Stuck.
articles.snippet: A small Egyptian village has a front-row seat to the unfolding effort to dislodge the container ship that ran aground in the canal, holding up $10 billion in global trade every day.
articles.abstract: A small Egyptian village has a front-row seat to the unfolding effort to dislodge the container ship that ran aground in the canal, holding up $10 billion in global trade every day.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: After nearly a week, the Ever Given, the mammoth container ship stuck in the Suez Canal, has been freed.]

articles.headline: They Were Guantánamo’s First Detainees. Here’s Where They Are Now.
articles.snippet: The Pentagon called the first 20 prisoners sent to Guantánamo in 2002 “the worst of the worst.” Just two remain there. Others are spread around the world — including four senior Taliban figures.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon called the first 20 prisoners sent to Guantánamo in 2002 “the worst of the worst.” Just two remain there. Others are spread around the world — including four senior Taliban figures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Jan. 11, 2002, at the desolate air strip at Guantánamo Bay, United States Marines escorted 20 prisoners clad in orange uniforms from an Air Force cargo plane — “the worst of the worst,” the Pentagon called them — making them the first inmates of the wartime detention center that remains open to this day.

articles.headline: Under Biden, Democrats Are Poised to Raise Taxes on Business and the Rich
articles.snippet: The president’s infrastructure proposals are likely to require trillions of dollars in new tax revenue. They also give liberals a chance to address what they call the failures of Republican tax cuts.
articles.abstract: The president’s infrastructure proposals are likely to require trillions of dollars in new tax revenue. They also give liberals a chance to address what they call the failures of Republican tax cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats have spent the last several years clamoring to raise taxes on corporations and the rich, seeing that as a necessary antidote to widening economic inequality and a rebuke of President Donald J. Trump’s signature tax cuts.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: An Immigrant Family Caught Up in a Distinctly American Tragedy
articles.snippet: The suspect in the mass shooting at a Colorado supermarket came from an immigrant family that had achieved many of the outward signs of success. But their life in America had not been untroubled.
articles.abstract: The suspect in the mass shooting at a Colorado supermarket came from an immigrant family that had achieved many of the outward signs of success. But their life in America had not been untroubled.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARVADA, Colo. — Two decades after they left Syria for a new home in the Rocky Mountains, it looked from the outside as if the Alissa family had made it in America.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Stephanie Saul, Ali Watkins, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sara Aridi

articles.headline: The Swift Collapse of a Company Built on Debt
articles.snippet: Greensill Capital promised a win-win for buyers and sellers, until it all fell apart, igniting concerns about opaque accounting practices.
articles.abstract: Greensill Capital promised a win-win for buyers and sellers, until it all fell apart, igniting concerns about opaque accounting practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The courthouse should have already been closed for the day.
articles.byline: By Eshe Nelson, Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Ten Months After George Floyd’s Death, Minneapolis Residents Are at War Over Policing
articles.snippet: As the trial of a former officer accused of murdering Mr. Floyd starts, residents and community leaders have struggled to reach consensus on how to radically change public safety, and the role that the police should play in that.
articles.abstract: As the trial of a former officer accused of murdering Mr. Floyd starts, residents and community leaders have struggled to reach consensus on how to radically change public safety, and the role that the police should play in that.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyd’s Death]
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Inside Myanmar’s Army: ‘They See Protesters as Criminals’
articles.snippet: Four officers spoke about life in the feared Tatmadaw, which has turned its guns on civilians again. “The Tatmadaw is the only world” for most soldiers, one said.
articles.abstract: Four officers spoke about life in the feared Tatmadaw, which has turned its guns on civilians again. “The Tatmadaw is the only world” for most soldiers, one said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capt. Tun Myat Aung leaned over the hot pavement in Yangon, Myanmar’s largest city, and picked up bullet casings. Nausea crept into his throat. The shells, he knew, meant that rifles had been used, real bullets fired at real people.

articles.headline: As Militants Seize Mozambique Gas Hub, a Dash for Safety Turns Deadly
articles.snippet: An agonizing choice for nearly 200 people holed up in a hotel as gunmen roamed unchecked: Wait overnight for rescue? Or make a run for it?
articles.abstract: An agonizing choice for nearly 200 people holed up in a hotel as gunmen roamed unchecked: Wait overnight for rescue? Or make a run for it?
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — As gunshots rang out across a port town in northeastern Mozambique on Friday afternoon, nearly 200 people sheltering inside the Amarula Palma hotel confronted a devastating reality: The armed insurgents outside the hotel’s doors had all but taken control of the town and there was no one coming to save them any time soon.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum, Eric Schmitt and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Inside America’s Most Interesting Magazine, and Media’s Oddest Workplace
articles.snippet: The publication of the “Harper’s letter” attracted huge attention. Most people had stopped reading the magazine, which is stranger and better than you might expect.
articles.abstract: The publication of the “Harper’s letter” attracted huge attention. Most people had stopped reading the magazine, which is stranger and better than you might expect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last August, when the pandemic seemed endless, John R. MacArthur, the publisher of Harper’s, asked his doctor about the virus.

articles.headline: Contentious Union Vote at Amazon Heads to a Count
articles.snippet: The outcome of a vote at a warehouse in Alabama could have far-ranging implications for both the company and the labor movement.
articles.abstract: The outcome of a vote at a warehouse in Alabama could have far-ranging implications for both the company and the labor movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — By the end of Monday, thousands of yellow envelopes mailed to a squat brick building in Birmingham, Ala., will hold the fate of one of the most closely watched union elections in recent history, one that could alter the shape of the labor movement and one of America’s largest employers.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Why Transgender Girls Are Suddenly the G.O.P.’s Culture-War Focus
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in a growing number of Republican-led states are advancing and passing bills to bar transgender athletes in girls’ sports, a culture clash that seems to have come out of nowhere.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in a growing number of Republican-led states are advancing and passing bills to bar transgender athletes in girls’ sports, a culture clash that seems to have come out of nowhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time Republicans in South Dakota made a serious push to bar transgender girls from school sports, in 2019, their bill was known only by its nondescript numerical title, Senate Bill 49. Its two main sponsors were men. And it died without ever getting out of committee, just 10 days after it was introduced.
